attributes.alt: Cover for Weather by National Geographic Kids. Cover shows a large tornado.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to introduce the book and identify it as an informational text about weather.
Use Circle Time to introduce the vocabulary word
Use Circle Time to introduce the letters
Begin story time by introducing the Big Book and asking,
What kind of weather did you learn about?
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in text.
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.
What type of weather do you see in your book?
Can you pretend to be a weather person? What is the weather today?
Look out the window. What would you tell a friend about the weather today?
Can you write about what you like to do on rainy days?
What can you make to keep you dry in the rain?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you use the blocks to build a tall weather tower? What can you see from the top of the tower?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Start Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Join two or more words to create a compound word.
Understand conventions of print including end punctuation and case.
Use information to categorize. Relate own experiments to those in books.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.
Use technology, including learning applications, to express own ideas.
Show children the basic steps of an experiment and allow children to make predictions and observations.
Can you show me your favorite kind of weather in a book?
Can you pretend to be a windstorm?
Can you explain how rain falls?
What question about the weather can you write? Can you make a question mark at the end?
Can you make a rainbow? Can you show all the colors?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you build something to keep people safe and dry during a thunderstorm?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to discuss basic needs related to weather and teach vocabulary
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Join two or more words to create a compound word; Blend two or more syllables to create a word.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.
Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.
Review with children that there are different kinds of clouds and they can tell us something about the weather.
Guide children to expand science vocabulary.
How many question marks can you find in your book? How many periods?
Can you pretend to be in a snowstorm? How would you walk on a very windy day?
Can you draw a rainbow? How many colors did you use?
Can you write about the three kinds of clouds?
Can you make a cloud with the materials?
Can you find the letter at the beginning of the word
Can you build a snow fort by using blocks?

attributes.alt:
Big Chart of Big Ideas for What's the Weather? Chart shows 4 different types of weather: rainy, snowy, windy, and sunny. 
Chart shows a child in a rain coat with an umbrella next to the word "rainy,"a child in a winter coat holding a snowball next to the word "snowy,"a child running with a kite in the grass next to the word "windy,"and two children building sandcastles at the beach next to the word "sunny."
Cover for Weather by National Geographic Kids. Cover shows a large tornado.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about weather. Introduce vocabulary
Start Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to the Concept Question:
Compare and contrast two stories relating to the same topic.
Understand conventions of print, including end punctuation and case.
Compose an informative text; Share and celebrate written products; Use top to bottom and left to right directionality when writing.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.
Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.
Review the Big Chart of Big Ideas.
Guide children as they create a book about weather.
Encourage children to work as a team.
Can you find labels in your book?
Can you think about and put on the clothes you should wear for a snowy day?
How many sunny-day activities can you think of? Take a Counter for each activity you name. How many counters did you get?
Can you write about the weather you like best?
Can you create something that sounds like a rainstorm?
Find the letter at the beginning of the word
Can you build a kite? Can you build an umbrella?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to actively engage children and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question:
How can you plan for the weather?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and enjoyment.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Participate in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Use information to describe; Use information to compare and contrast; Relate own experiences to those in books.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.
Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
If you could control the weather, what kind of weather would you make?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
If you wrote a story about weather, what would it be?
Can you pretend to be rain? Snow? Hail? Sun? Wind? Lightning and thunder?
Can you imagine a lot of snow? Show how tall the snow is using Connecting Cubes.
Can you write a story about wild weather?
Can you invent a weather machine? What materials will you use?
’s can you find around the room?
Can you build a shelter that goes with your favorite kind of weather?
